href=\'/p/advertising-with-hacker-news.html\'>Advertise with us</a></li> </ul> </div> </nav> <div class=\'gap\'></div> <div class=\'o-h5\'>Contact/Tip Us</div> <div class=\'o-contact\'> <a research, hacks, or ask us a question or leave a comment/feedback!</span> </a> </div> <div class=\'gap\'></div> <div class=\'o-h5\'>Follow Us On Social Media</div> <div class=\'o-follow cf\'> <a href=\'https://www.facebook.com/thehackernews\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-facebook\'>&#61594;</i></a> <a href=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' rel=\'noopener\' </div> </div> </aside> <div class=\'rocking cf\'> <div class=\'header-cn\'> <a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/devsecops-wiz-d\' rel=\'noopener noreferrer\' target=\'_blank\'><img alt=\'DevSecOps\' data-src=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjx2cij7Zn_6jyxVOFUQZbJbb2JTi4ET4hn1qvv6YJI6WBbqOST0FE4F-BthBp7vTkOaP6sCiKkodkcm166yEXmR-_bNspTHdojFi3LAhmyaDjZjpqOi4qSDkJY7j8Hy0oh8iE6PqLaVh_K8sh3a8kcwJOPU-hjyeT6tqvNfxY6qYX3SqFW611E6aoadZz_/s728-rw-e100/devsecops-wiz-d.png\' height=\'91\' loading=\'lazy\' src=\'data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=\' width=\'729\'/></a> </div> </div> <main class=\'main clear\'> <div class=\'main-box clear\'> <!--Item Page--> <h1 class=\'story-title\'><a href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html">Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts</a></h1> <div class=\'main-left-right clear\'> <div class=\'left-box\' id=\'left-box\'> <div class=\'content section\' id=\'content\'><div class=\'widget Blog\' data-version=\'1\' id=\'Blog1\'> <div class=\'blog-posts clear\'> <div class=\'post\'> <div class=\'post-body\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/NewsArticle\'> <link href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html" itemprop=\'mainEntityOfPage url\' /> <meta content=\'Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts\' itemprop=\'headline\'/> <meta content=\'en-US\' itemprop=\'inLanguage\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T18:33:00+05:30\' itemprop=\'datePublished\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T13:08:36Z\' itemprop=\'dateModified\'/> <div itemprop=\'image\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'728\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'380\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div> <div itemprop=\'publisher\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Organization\'><meta content=\'The Hacker News\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/\' itemprop=\'url\'/><div content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'logo\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'460\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'60\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div></div> <div itemprop=\'author\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Person\'><meta content=\'Ravie Lakshmanan\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' itemprop=\'url\'/></div> <div class=\'clear post-head\'> <div class=\'postmeta\'><span class=\'p-author\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i><span class=\'author\'>Feb 05, 2025</span><i class=\'icon-font icon-user\'>&#59396;</i><span class=\'author\'>Ravie Lakshmanan</span></span><span class=\'p-tags\'>Cybersecurity / Cloud Security</span></div></div> <div class=\'articlebody clear cf\' id=\'articlebody\'><div class="separator" style="clear: both;"><a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v2-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhT2OnXk97z-adL5WBKzz6wsA7vAhygg3Px0VPmqpH5hH4AErnYajTCpDN7SLy43ejD_T4Skv8OMOdG9qpzMfihrj8o7qSznLKA8zg7jW8L4hY8-umwTNZSpAj0JvtG3VGMFGw9n7hMyea1NpVSXp6yTaClLUQ3GujxwlEuLmQFSsVH28WQy6vp-cOGG0p_/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v2-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting?  Follow us on <a href=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>Twitter <i class=\'icon-font icon-twitter\'>&#61593;</i></a> and <a href=\'https://www.linkedin.com/company/thehackernews/\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>LinkedIn</a> to read more exclusive content we post.</div> </div> <script data-cfasync=\'false\'> var <div class=\'pop-title\'>How Long Does It Take Hackers to Crack Modern Hashing Algorithms?</div> </div> </a> </div> <div class=\'cf pop-article clear\'> <a class=\'pop-link cf\' (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.  \n According to Proofpoint, these tools (sourced originally from public repositories like GitHub) are being leveraged to facilitate sophisticated techniques such as Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) attacks and brute force password spraying.  \n By late 2024, about 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants had been targeted by ATO attempts, with the peak of these attacks occurring in May 2024 when millions of hijacked residential IPs were deployed.  \n In one particular campaign, Node Fetch and Go Resty tools were utilized in a large-scale password spraying operation that recorded at least 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day.  \n Despite the high volume of attempts, the success rate of the password spraying campaign was low, impacting only around 2% of targeted entities.  \n More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across approximately 3,000 organizations have been identified, with a significant portion belonging to the education sector (particularly less protected student accounts), making them lucrative for further exploitation or sale.  \n Attackers have also been observed establishing new mailbox rules to hide their activity, stealing sensitive data, and registering new OAuth applications with excessive permissions to maintain persistent remote access to compromised environments.  \n The Axios client, designed for Node.js and browsers, is being combined with AitM platforms such as Evilginx to steal both credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes, and these targeted attacks predominantly focus on high-value roles such as executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across multiple industries.  \n Between June and November 2024, over 51% of the targeted organizations were successfully impacted, with approximately 43% of targeted user accounts compromised during this period.  \n Security researcher Anna Akselevich notes content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'460\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'60\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div></div> <div itemprop=\'author\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Person\'><meta content=\'Ravie Lakshmanan\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' itemprop=\'url\'/></div> <div class=\'clear post-head\'> <div class=\'postmeta\'><span class=\'p-author\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i><span class=\'author\'>Feb 05, 2025</span><i class=\'icon-font icon-user\'>&#59396;</i><span class=\'author\'>Ravie Lakshmanan</span></span><span class=\'p-tags\'>Cybersecurity / Cloud Security</span></div></div> <div class=\'articlebody clear cf\' id=\'articlebody\'><div class="separator" style="clear: both;"><a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v1-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhc0hgq4JZKi-PJjUZ4kdb5ficmXr3IPOg6noFF558_qZ-gXm7vb0OzXU0NzsPAxaqca2tLI5j8NgJW731W0_CuPrUerOmSrZSt4IeANQp6VAQsIAQUzv6aJsxBD6poxHfELq0bcbeevSVy5AyOb9ganALMoA140nZoLOtSb0ck2AZ5rZgb9mWDEyVsbvqK/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v1-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting?  Follow us on <a href=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>Twitter <i class=\'icon-font icon-twitter\'>&#61593;</i></a> and <a href=\'https://www.linkedin.com/company/thehackernews/\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>LinkedIn</a> to read more exclusive content we post.</div> </div> <script data-cfasync=\'false\'> var DeepSeek AI Over Data Privacy and Ethical Concerns\' border=\'0\' class=\'lazyload\' decoding=\'async\' height=\'72\' src=\'data:image/svg+xml;base64,\' title=\'Italy Bans Chinese DeepSeek AI Over Data Privacy and Ethical Concerns\' width=\'72\'/> </figure> </div> <div {max-width:728px;} .email-box p {text-align:center}  .f-menu-cl-1,.f-menu-cl-2,.f-menu-cl-3,.f-menu-cl-4,.social-box {width:33.33%} .social-box i {font-size:25px;width:50px;height:50px;line-height:50px} .f-menu-cl-3 {display:none} .header_big,.header_unit {width:728px;height:90px;margin:0 auto} .f-rss {display:block} }  @media only screen and (min-width:889px) { body {font-size:16px;line-height:28px;background:radial-gradient(circle, #d4e1ff 20%, rgba(255, 255, 255, 1) 100%);} .gap {height:30px} .rocking, .webinar-con {padding:20px;min-height:130px}  .left-box {width:calc(100% - 300px);padding:0 3.4% 0 0;float:left} .rightbx {width:300px;padding:0;float:left} .home-desc{display:none} .p-tags {display:inline-block} .mobile-share {display:none;visibility:hidden}    .expert-card{max-width:23.8%;min-width:23.8%;margin-right:1.6%;margin-bottom:0} .expert-card:last-child{margin-right:0} .expert-card-headline{font-size:16px;line-height:25px;min-height:78px;} .expert-label{display:block;}    .latest,.latest:nth-child(2n+0) {margin-right:1.6%} .latest-desc,.rightbx {display:block} .latest {width:23.8%;float:left;margin-bottom:10px} .latest:nth-child(4n+0) {margin-right:0} .latest-h3 {font-size:16px;line-height:25px;margin-bottom:10px;min-height:65px;} .below-post-box,.main-box {max-width:1110px}  .f-menu-cl-1,.f-menu-cl-2,.f-menu-cl-3,.f-menu-cl-4 {width:25%} .f-menu-cl-3{display:block} .social-box {width:16.66%} }  @media only screen and (min-width:1150px) { .top-bar-box {padding:0 20px} .logo-area,.menu-more,.menu-ul li,.search-here {padding:0 20px} .eight_plus {display:inline-block}  .main {padding:35px 0 0} .main-left-right {padding:0 20px 20px} .left-box {line-height:48px;font-size:32px;padding:0 20px;} .comment-box {padding:20px}  .below-post-box {padding:20px 20px 0}  .f-menu-cl {width:25%} .footer-stuff {padding:20px 20px 5px} }  @media only screen and (min-width:1220px) { .float-share,.rightbx {display:block} }    .slogan-container{display: inline;}.glitch{position:relative;animation:1s linear infinite alternate-reverse alternate-reverse glitch-anim2}@keyframes glitch-anim2{0%{clip:rect(65px,9999px,33px,0)}15%{clip:rect(87px,9999px,74px,0)}30%{clip:rect(18px,9999px,36px,0)}45%{clip:rect(25px,9999px,6px,0)}60%{clip:rect(73px,9999px,55px,0)}75%{clip:rect(56px,9999px,88px,0)}90%{clip:rect(43px,9999px,15px,0)}100%{clip:rect(78px,9999px,30px,0)}}@keyframes glitch-skew{0%,40%{transform:skew(-2deg)}10%,100%,50%{transform:skew(-1deg)}20%,90%{transform:skew(3deg)}30%,80%{transform:skew(1deg)}60%{transform:skew(2deg)}70%{transform:skew(-3deg)}}.cursor{display: inline-block; width: 5px; height: 12px; background-color: #9997FF; margin-left:4px; animation: .7s infinite blink; vertical-align: middle;}@keyframes blink{0%,100%{opacity:0}50%{opacity:1}} </style> </div> </div> </aside> <div class=\'rocking cf\'> <div class=\'header-cn\'> <a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/devsecops-wiz-d\' rel=\'noopener noreferrer\' target=\'_blank\'><img alt=\'DevSecOps\' data-src=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjx2cij7Zn_6jyxVOFUQZbJbb2JTi4ET4hn1qvv6YJI6WBbqOST0FE4F-BthBp7vTkOaP6sCiKkodkcm166yEXmR-_bNspTHdojFi3LAhmyaDjZjpqOi4qSDkJY7j8Hy0oh8iE6PqLaVh_K8sh3a8kcwJOPU-hjyeT6tqvNfxY6qYX3SqFW611E6aoadZz_/s728-rw-e100/devsecops-wiz-d.png\' height=\'91\' loading=\'lazy\' src=\'data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=\' width=\'729\'/></a> </div> </div> <main class=\'main clear\'> <div class=\'main-box clear\'> <!--Item Page--> <h1 class=\'story-title\'><a href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html">Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts</a></h1> <div class=\'main-left-right clear\'> <div class=\'left-box\' id=\'left-box\'> <div class=\'content section\' id=\'content\'><div class=\'widget Blog\' data-version=\'1\' id=\'Blog1\'> <div class=\'blog-posts clear\'> <div class=\'post\'> <div class=\'post-body\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/NewsArticle\'> <link href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html" itemprop=\'mainEntityOfPage url\' /> <meta content=\'Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts\' itemprop=\'headline\'/> <meta content=\'en-US\' itemprop=\'inLanguage\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T18:33:00+05:30\' itemprop=\'datePublished\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T13:08:36Z\' itemprop=\'dateModified\'/> <div itemprop=\'image\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'728\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'380\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div> <div itemprop=\'publisher\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Organization\'><meta content=\'The Hacker News\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/\' itemprop=\'url\'/><div content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'logo\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'460\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'60\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div></div> <div itemprop=\'author\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Person\'><meta content=\'Ravie Lakshmanan\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' itemprop=\'url\'/></div> <div class=\'clear post-head\'> <div class=\'postmeta\'><span class=\'p-author\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i><span class=\'author\'>Feb 05, 2025</span><i class=\'icon-font icon-user\'>&#59396;</i><span class=\'author\'>Ravie Lakshmanan</span></span><span class=\'p-tags\'>Cybersecurity / Cloud Security</span></div></div> <div class=\'articlebody clear cf\' id=\'articlebody\'><div class="separator" style="clear: both;"><a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v2-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhT2OnXk97z-adL5WBKzz6wsA7vAhygg3Px0VPmqpH5hH4AErnYajTCpDN7SLy43ejD_T4Skv8OMOdG9qpzMfihrj8o7qSznLKA8zg7jW8L4hY8-umwTNZSpAj0JvtG3VGMFGw9n7hMyea1NpVSXp6yTaClLUQ3GujxwlEuLmQFSsVH28WQy6vp-cOGG0p_/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v2-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting?  Follow us on <a href=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>Twitter <i class=\'icon-font icon-twitter\'>&#61593;</i></a> and <a Now give the factsheet for the following information:  Cybercriminals are exploiting legitimate HTTP client librariesincluding Go Resty and Node Fetchto carry out largescale password spraying and account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.  \n According to Proofpoints observations, these tools originally come from public repositories (such as GitHub) and are now used in combination with techniques like AdversaryintheMiddle (AitM) and brute-force to compromise accounts.  \n A diverse set of HTTP clients is being employed by attackers, including Axios (which can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to steal credentials and MFA codes), Node Fetch, Go Resty, and Python Requests.  \n In May 2024, attackers peaked their efforts by leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs, leading to 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants being targeted by at least one ATO attempt during the second half of 2024.  \n A specific campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty recorded approximately 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per daydespite a low overall success rate of around 2%.  \n The attackers are not only attempting login breaches but are also setting up mailbox rules to hide malicious activity, stealing sensitive data, and even registering new OAuth applications with excessive permission scopes to secure persistent remote access.  \n The Axios-driven campaign specifically targeted high-value individuals such as executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across sectors like transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare.  \n Over 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been compromised to date, with a significant number of these belonging to the education sector (including largely underprotected student accounts), which could later be exploited further or sold to other threat actors.'}], 'model': 'gpt-3.5-turbo-16k'}}

class=\'main clear\'> <div class=\'main-box clear\'> <!--Item Page--> <h1 class=\'story-title\'><a href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html">Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts</a></h1> <div class=\'main-left-right clear\'> <div class=\'left-box\' id=\'left-box\'> <div class=\'content section\' id=\'content\'><div class=\'widget Blog\' data-version=\'1\' id=\'Blog1\'> <div class=\'blog-posts clear\'> <div class=\'post\'> <div class=\'post-body\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/NewsArticle\'> <link href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html" itemprop=\'mainEntityOfPage url\' /> <meta content=\'Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts\' itemprop=\'headline\'/> <meta content=\'en-US\' itemprop=\'inLanguage\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T18:33:00+05:30\' itemprop=\'datePublished\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T13:08:36Z\' itemprop=\'dateModified\'/> <div itemprop=\'image\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'728\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'380\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div> <div itemprop=\'publisher\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Organization\'><meta content=\'The Hacker News\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/\' itemprop=\'url\'/><div content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'logo\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'460\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'60\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div></div> <div itemprop=\'author\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Person\'><meta content=\'Ravie Lakshmanan\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' itemprop=\'url\'/></div> <div class=\'clear post-head\'> <div class=\'postmeta\'><span class=\'p-author\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i><span class=\'author\'>Feb 05, 2025</span><i class=\'icon-font icon-user\'>&#59396;</i><span class=\'author\'>Ravie Lakshmanan</span></span><span class=\'p-tags\'>Cybersecurity / Cloud Security</span></div></div> <div class=\'articlebody clear cf\' id=\'articlebody\'><div class="separator" style="clear: both;"><a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v1-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhc0hgq4JZKi-PJjUZ4kdb5ficmXr3IPOg6noFF558_qZ-gXm7vb0OzXU0NzsPAxaqca2tLI5j8NgJW731W0_CuPrUerOmSrZSt4IeANQp6VAQsIAQUzv6aJsxBD6poxHfELq0bcbeevSVy5AyOb9ganALMoA140nZoLOtSb0ck2AZ5rZgb9mWDEyVsbvqK/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v1-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting? class=\'pop-desc\'> <div class=\'pop-title\'>U.S. and Dutch Authorities Dismantle 39 Domains Linked to BEC Fraud Network</div> </div> </a> </div> <div class=\'cf pop-article clear last-three\'> <a class=\'pop-link cf\' href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/01/google-over-57-nation-state-threat.html"> <div class=\'side-pop-image\'> <figure class=\'pop-image\'> <img alt=\'Google: Over 57 Nation-State Threat Groups Using AI for Cyber Operations\' border=\'0\' class=\'lazyload\' class=\'pop-desc\'> <div class=\'pop-title\'>Google: Over 57 Nation-State Threat Groups Using AI for Cyber Operations</div> </div> </a> </div> <div class=\'cf pop-article clear last-three\'> <a class=\'main clear\'> <div class=\'main-box clear\'> <!--Item Page--> <h1 class=\'story-title\'><a href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html">Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts</a></h1> <div class=\'main-left-right clear\'> <div class=\'left-box\' id=\'left-box\'> <div class=\'content section\' id=\'content\'><div class=\'widget Blog\' data-version=\'1\' id=\'Blog1\'> <div class=\'blog-posts clear\'> <div class=\'post\'> <div class=\'post-body\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/NewsArticle\'> <link href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html" itemprop=\'mainEntityOfPage url\' /> <meta content=\'Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts\' itemprop=\'headline\'/> <meta content=\'en-US\' itemprop=\'inLanguage\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T18:33:00+05:30\' itemprop=\'datePublished\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T13:08:36Z\' itemprop=\'dateModified\'/> <div itemprop=\'image\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'728\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'380\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div> <div itemprop=\'publisher\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Organization\'><meta content=\'The Hacker News\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/\' itemprop=\'url\'/><div content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'logo\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'460\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'60\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div></div> <div itemprop=\'author\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Person\'><meta content=\'Ravie Lakshmanan\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' itemprop=\'url\'/></div> <div class=\'clear post-head\'> <div class=\'postmeta\'><span class=\'p-author\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i><span class=\'author\'>Feb 05, 2025</span><i class=\'icon-font icon-user\'>&#59396;</i><span class=\'author\'>Ravie Lakshmanan</span></span><span class=\'p-tags\'>Cybersecurity / Cloud Security</span></div></div> <div class=\'articlebody clear cf\' id=\'articlebody\'><div class="separator" style="clear: both;"><a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v2-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhT2OnXk97z-adL5WBKzz6wsA7vAhygg3Px0VPmqpH5hH4AErnYajTCpDN7SLy43ejD_T4Skv8OMOdG9qpzMfihrj8o7qSznLKA8zg7jW8L4hY8-umwTNZSpAj0JvtG3VGMFGw9n7hMyea1NpVSXp6yTaClLUQ3GujxwlEuLmQFSsVH28WQy6vp-cOGG0p_/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v2-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting?  Follow us on <a href=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>Twitter <i class=\'icon-font icon-twitter\'>&#61593;</i></a> and <a class=\'pop-desc\'> <div class=\'pop-title\'>&#9889; THN Weekly Recap: Top Cybersecurity Threats, Tools and Tips [3 February]</div> </div> </a> </div> <div class=\'cf pop-article clear\'> <a src=\'data:image/svg+xml;base64,\'/> <h2 class=\'expert-card-headline\'>Eliminate Your Attack Surface by Becoming Invisible: Hackers Can\'t Attack What They Can\'t See</h2> <div class=\'expert-label\'> <span class=\'expert-datetime\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i>February 3, 2024</span> <span class=\'expert-tags\' style=\'\'>Read &#10141;</span> </div> </a> <a class=\'expert-card\' href=\'https://thehackernews.com/expert-insights/2025/02/using-roles-and-attributes-to-protect.html\' rel=\'\' style=\'text-decoration: none; color: inherit;\'> <img content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'logo\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'460\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'60\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div></div> <div itemprop=\'author\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Person\'><meta content=\'Ravie Lakshmanan\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' itemprop=\'url\'/></div> <div class=\'clear post-head\'> <div class=\'postmeta\'><span class=\'p-author\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i><span class=\'author\'>Feb 05, 2025</span><i class=\'icon-font icon-user\'>&#59396;</i><span class=\'author\'>Ravie Lakshmanan</span></span><span class=\'p-tags\'>Cybersecurity / Cloud Security</span></div></div> <div class=\'articlebody clear cf\' id=\'articlebody\'><div class="separator" style="clear: both;"><a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v2-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhT2OnXk97z-adL5WBKzz6wsA7vAhygg3Px0VPmqpH5hH4AErnYajTCpDN7SLy43ejD_T4Skv8OMOdG9qpzMfihrj8o7qSznLKA8zg7jW8L4hY8-umwTNZSpAj0JvtG3VGMFGw9n7hMyea1NpVSXp6yTaClLUQ3GujxwlEuLmQFSsVH28WQy6vp-cOGG0p_/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v2-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting?  Follow us on <a href=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>Twitter <i class=\'icon-font icon-twitter\'>&#61593;</i></a> and <a href=\'https://www.linkedin.com/company/thehackernews/\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>LinkedIn</a> to read more exclusive content we post.</div> </div> <script data-cfasync=\'false\'> var class=\'pop-link cf\' href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/01/italy-bans-chinese-deepseek-ai-over.html"> <div class=\'side-pop-image\'> <figure class=\'pop-image\'> <img alt=\'Italy Bans Chinese DeepSeek AI Over Data Privacy and Ethical Concerns\' border=\'0\' class=\'lazyload\' </div> </div> </aside> <div class=\'rocking cf\'> <div class=\'header-cn\'> <a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/devsecops-wiz-d\' rel=\'noopener noreferrer\' target=\'_blank\'><img alt=\'DevSecOps\' data-src=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjx2cij7Zn_6jyxVOFUQZbJbb2JTi4ET4hn1qvv6YJI6WBbqOST0FE4F-BthBp7vTkOaP6sCiKkodkcm166yEXmR-_bNspTHdojFi3LAhmyaDjZjpqOi4qSDkJY7j8Hy0oh8iE6PqLaVh_K8sh3a8kcwJOPU-hjyeT6tqvNfxY6qYX3SqFW611E6aoadZz_/s728-rw-e100/devsecops-wiz-d.png\' height=\'91\' loading=\'lazy\' src=\'data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=\' width=\'729\'/></a> </div> </div> <main class=\'main clear\'> <div class=\'main-box clear\'> <!--Item Page--> <h1 class=\'story-title\'><a href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html">Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts</a></h1> <div class=\'main-left-right clear\'> <div class=\'left-box\' id=\'left-box\'> <div class=\'content section\' id=\'content\'><div class=\'widget Blog\' data-version=\'1\' id=\'Blog1\'> <div class=\'blog-posts clear\'> <div class=\'post\'> <div class=\'post-body\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/NewsArticle\'> <link href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/02/cybercriminals-use-axios-and-node-fetch.html" itemprop=\'mainEntityOfPage url\' /> <meta content=\'Cybercriminals Use Go Resty and Node Fetch in 13 Million Password Spraying Attempts\' itemprop=\'headline\'/> <meta content=\'en-US\' itemprop=\'inLanguage\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T18:33:00+05:30\' itemprop=\'datePublished\'/> <meta content=\'2025-02-05T13:08:36Z\' itemprop=\'dateModified\'/> <div itemprop=\'image\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'728\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'380\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div> <div itemprop=\'publisher\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Organization\'><meta content=\'The Hacker News\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/\' itemprop=\'url\'/><div content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'logo\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/ImageObject\'><meta content=\'https://thehackernews.com/images/-lr1jzOJlY3g/Wzjug8yO0UI/AAAAAAAAxSk/pVpxFhgIHRcIbASdYo3YSDZLB8p3ytjqACLcBGAs/s460-rw-e365/the-hacker-news.jpg\' itemprop=\'url\'/><meta content=\'460\' itemprop=\'width\'/><meta content=\'60\' itemprop=\'height\'/></div></div> <div itemprop=\'author\' itemscope=\'\' itemtype=\'https://schema.org/Person\'><meta content=\'Ravie Lakshmanan\' itemprop=\'name\'/><meta content=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' itemprop=\'url\'/></div> <div class=\'clear post-head\'> <div class=\'postmeta\'><span class=\'p-author\'><i class=\'icon-font icon-calendar\'>&#59394;</i><span class=\'author\'>Feb 05, 2025</span><i class=\'icon-font icon-user\'>&#59396;</i><span class=\'author\'>Ravie Lakshmanan</span></span><span class=\'p-tags\'>Cybersecurity / Cloud Security</span></div></div> <div class=\'articlebody clear cf\' id=\'articlebody\'><div class="separator" style="clear: both;"><a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v1-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhc0hgq4JZKi-PJjUZ4kdb5ficmXr3IPOg6noFF558_qZ-gXm7vb0OzXU0NzsPAxaqca2tLI5j8NgJW731W0_CuPrUerOmSrZSt4IeANQp6VAQsIAQUzv6aJsxBD6poxHfELq0bcbeevSVy5AyOb9ganALMoA140nZoLOtSb0ck2AZ5rZgb9mWDEyVsbvqK/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v1-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting?  Follow us on <a href=\'https://twitter.com/thehackersnews\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>Twitter <i class=\'icon-font icon-twitter\'>&#61593;</i></a> and <a href=\'https://www.linkedin.com/company/thehackernews/\' rel=\'noopener\' target=\'_blank\'>LinkedIn</a> to read more exclusive content we post.</div> </div> <script data-cfasync=\'false\'> var encodeURIComponent(share_title); </script> <meta content=\'4802841478634147276\' name=\'blogId\'/> <meta content=\'6100631150505085977\' name=\'postId\'/> <div class=\'schema_org\'></div> <div href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" style="display: block;  text-align: center; clear: left; float: left;"><img data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjYcB32bkzUF1AUr0lZ-QhdBoLLvnT73Shfa_xeGfbzGcBDUBqpyPKsM8S2JQTYp2QPGEz9VYJtSjJQyPoaq62xn45twN9602Yhyphenhyphen2oaCfmumyoGw_m7b9zmIzDVJ4rtwEIe7veBBkkObIMddQ2IOKjt81JpF3aCJmPHikqQqDQwGUOk2Z3KPxOrkKRfKHDg/s728-rw-e365/pssword.png" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" alt="" border="0" data-original-height="380" data-original-width="728" /></a></div>  <p>Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging legitimate HTTP client tools to facilitate account takeover (ATO) attacks on Microsoft 365 environments.</p> <p>Enterprise security company Proofpoint said it observed campaigns using HTTP clients Axios and Node Fetch to send HTTP requests and receive HTTP responses from web servers with the goal of conducting ATO attacks.</p> <p>"Originally sourced from public repositories like GitHub, these tools are increasingly used in attacks like Adversary-in-the-Middle (AitM) and brute force techniques, leading to numerous account takeover (ATO) incidents," security researcher Anna Akselevich <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/http-client-tools-exploitation-account-takeover-attacks" rel="noopener" target="_blank">said</a>.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/encrypted-attacks-report-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh6e4c8i_pkXRCFnrtqVIygOrARiVnU3_KUgU5mhPl5V4uj8R1KcQOxRLdZ0xm1Rf5AX_cviUAeiiRkTJCe8HXzOeB363590NBXAMv92N9e7zr4m7aKtDq-Q_gpP9QFWecL0oxcVtmqSg9qrGEGqlDbzwNNFKGJe2nlup4tuL7AZzTm0U501YxPGodOc2Fq/s728-rw-e100/zz-d.jpg" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The use of HTTP client tools for brute-force attacks has been a long-observed trend since at least February 2018, with successive iterations employing variants of OkHttp clients to target Microsoft 365 environments at least until early 2024.</p> <p>But by March 2024, Proofpoint said it began to observe a wide range of HTTP clients gaining traction, with the attacks scaling a new high such that 78% of Microsoft 365 tenants were targeted at least once by an ATO attempt by the second half of last year.</p> <p>"In May 2024, these attacks peaked, leveraging millions of hijacked residential IPs to target cloud accounts," Akselevich said.</p> <p>The volume and diversity of these attack attempts is evidenced by the emergence of HTTP clients such as Axios, Go Resty, Node Fetch, and Python Requests, with those combining precision targeting with AitM techniques achieving a higher compromise rate.</p> <p>Axios, per Proofpoint, is designed for Node.js and browsers and can be paired with AitM platforms like Evilginx to enable theft of credentials and multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes.</p> <p>The threat actors have also been observed setting up new mailbox rules to conceal evidence of malicious activities, stealing sensitive data, and even registering a new OAuth application with excessive permission scopes to establish persistent remote access to the compromised environment.</p> <p>The Axios campaign is said to have primarily singled out high-value targets like executives, financial officers, account managers, and operational staff across transportation, construction, finance, IT, and healthcare verticals.</p> <p>Over 51% of the targeted organizations have been assessed to be successfully impacted between June and November 2024, compromising 43% of targeted user accounts.</p> <div class=\'dog_two clear\'><center class=\'cf\'><a href=\'https://thehackernews.uk/saas-security-v2-d\' rel=\'nofollow noopener sponsored\' target=\'_blank\' title=\'Cybersecurity\'><img class=\'lazyload\' alt="Cybersecurity" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8Xw8AAoMBgDTD2qgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=" data-src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhT2OnXk97z-adL5WBKzz6wsA7vAhygg3Px0VPmqpH5hH4AErnYajTCpDN7SLy43ejD_T4Skv8OMOdG9qpzMfihrj8o7qSznLKA8zg7jW8L4hY8-umwTNZSpAj0JvtG3VGMFGw9n7hMyea1NpVSXp6yTaClLUQ3GujxwlEuLmQFSsVH28WQy6vp-cOGG0p_/s728-rw-e100/saas-security-v2-d.png" width="727" height="90"/></a></center></div> <p>The cybersecurity company said it also detected a large-scale password spraying campaign using Node Fetch and Go Resty clients, recording no less than 13 million login attempts since June 9, 2024, averaging over 66,000 malicious attempts per day. The success rate, however, remained low, affecting only 2% of targeted entities.</p> <p>More than 178,000 targeted user accounts across 3,000 organizations have been identified to date, a majority of which belong to the education sector, particularly student user accounts that are likely to be less protected and can be weaponized for other campaigns or sold to different threat actors.</p> <p>"Threat actors\' tools for ATO attacks have greatly evolved, with various HTTP client tools used for exploiting APIs and making HTTP requests," Akselevich said. "These tools offer distinct advantages, making attacks more efficient."</p> <p>"Given this trend, attackers are likely to continue switching between HTTP client tools, adapting strategies to leverage new technologies and evade detection, reflecting a broader pattern of constant evolution to enhance their effectiveness and minimize exposure."</p> <br/> <div class=\'stophere\' id=\'hiddenH1\'></div> <div class=\'cf note-b\'>Found this article interesting? DeepSeek AI Over Data Privacy and Ethical Concerns\' border=\'0\' class=\'lazyload\'
